diagrams.caption: Simulating dual-unitary circuits with tensor-network error mitigation.

description: Many-body quantum chaos studies how complex quantum systems scramble information and thermalize. Dual-unitary circuits—which exhibit unitarity in both space and time—provide an ideal testbed because they display maximal chaos while remaining analytically solvable for certain observables.

Simulating chaotic dynamics is challenging for classical computers because entanglement grows rapidly, causing tensor network methods to fail. Quantum processors can naturally handle this entanglement growth, making chaotic systems a compelling target for near-term quantum advantage.

The kicked Ising model at the dual-unitary point provides exact analytical benchmarks for infinite-temperature autocorrelation functions, enabling rigorous verification of quantum simulation accuracy.
why_qem: Chaotic circuits rapidly spread errors throughout the system, making raw hardware results unreliable. Error mitigation is essential for extracting accurate dynamical correlators.

Tensor network error mitigation (TEM) constructs an approximate inverse of the noise channel, enabling efficient correction of spatially correlated errors without the exponential overhead of full process tomography.
Pauli twirling converts coherent gate errors into stochastic Pauli noise, which can be accurately characterized via a sparse Pauli-Lindblad model and inverted by TEM.
The combination of noise learning and TEM enables exploration of perturbed circuits beyond the exactly solvable dual-unitary point, where classical tensor network approximations struggle.

demonstrations.title: 91-Qubit Dual-Unitary Circuit Simulation (IBM, 2026)
demonstrations.description: Simulated infinite-temperature autocorrelation functions in dual-unitary circuits implementing kicked Ising dynamics. Error-mitigated results matched exact analytical solutions at the dual-unitary point and explored perturbed regimes beyond classical reach.
demonstrations.techniques: TEM, Pauli twirling, TREX (twirled readout error extinction), sparse Pauli-Lindblad noise model

challenges: Chaotic dynamics amplify small errors exponentially
Correlators decay rapidly, requiring precise measurement of small signals
Noise learning must accurately capture spatially correlated errors
Verification is only possible at exactly solvable points; perturbed regimes lack classical benchmarks
